comments.text:
My biggest objection to Professor Kaku's theory is the idea that a feedback 
loop tells the... say thermostat... something about the environment. Tells 
who? For a thermostat's feedback loop to tell it something about the 
environment one must already assume there's an "it" that is paying 
attention - it's a version of almost inescapable Cartesian dualism. The 
consciousness has been brought in the back door to receive the information 
the thermostat is relaying. A physicist would know that a thermostat is 
merely a piece of bi-metal: a strip of two metals layered on one another 
with different coefficients of expansion so that the strip bends when the 
temperature changes. Pass current through the strip and set contacts within 
its reach and you have an electrical switch sensitive to temperature. Or 
use the physical property itself. Your car "knows" when the engine has 
reached operating temperature and opens the thermostat to allow the cooling 
fluid to reach the radiator. But this kind of "knowing" and the confounding 
mystery of ego seem entirely different orders of things, at least to this 
observer...
comments.author: ThePeaceableKingdom

 The triune distinction is just based on gross morphological criteria. It 
is disproved by:
- histological research: the architecture of the neurons
- functional research: scans of the activity of the brain
- embryological research: the sequence of development in the embryo
For example, certain parts of the cerebellum develop at the very end of the 
embryonic development, at the same time as certain parts of the cerebral 
cortex.

You can argue that the goal of survival is instinctual and thus are all 
actions made in the direction of it, but that's missing the point.  A pack 
of wolves has a pup that is going to die if it doesn't eat soon.  Every 
single time this scenario occurs the wolves will do the same exact thing: 
hunt.  
A large family living in urban America has a newborn baby that they can't 
afford to feed.  They don't follow instinct and go foraging for food.  They 
view their situation with all the information they can gather and attempt 
to create a pattern that will solve their problem i.e. they all start 
singing on the streets for money to feed the baby.  But they could decide 
to do any number of things based on the circumstances.  The same family 
replaced in Africa would have to use completely different information to 
calculate a completely different solution.

But without minimal development of a frontal-lobe-esque organ, wouldn't any 
behavior that implicates planning towards the future be an evolutionary 
adaptation or learned behavior? For instances squirrels that stash food for 
the winter, finches that use twigs as tools to retrieve insects from 
crevasses then store them for later use or even otters that collect rocks 
that are well formed for smashing oyster shells. All of these animals adapt 
this behavior from heritage and mimicry and not from ingenuity. Perhaps to 
some extent, their comprehension of the applications of the behavior they 
observe as being beneficial, is evidence to the case, but aside from that, 
what animals *predict* the future without experience.

"Those kinds of animals could be said, in a limited way, to "plan," and in

comments.text:
+William Schultz
Yes, It comes from behaviours that are detrimental, not being genetically 
transferred to the next generation, and behaviours that will help those 
genes to be transferred, being re-enforced.

Have you ever heard of an 'extended phenotype?'  The nest of a dipper is 
globular, made of moss, lined with feathers and is a snug place for the 
dipper to bring up her young.  Where did the design of this nest come 
from?  The fact is, this nest *is* a genetic phenotype.  When I say this, 
people, especially creationists, say, 'how can it be a phenotype, nests 
have no genes,'  To which I answer, yes they do, the genes of this nest are 
in the dipper!

Orcas have huge brains compared to squirrels.  You might be right about 
them having more intelligence, but it's not out and out intelligence that 
makes humans so successful, it's language.  I don't know whether orcas have 
a sophisticated language or not; they certainly have a sophisticated social 
life and make a great variety of sounds.  But, in order to say to yourself, 
'I will do *___* today,' it is necessary to have the words in that sentence 
available in your mind (along with their meanings and associations) to make 
that decision at a human level.

There is no doubt that many intelligent animals are quite capable of 
producing an imaginary prediction of a scene in the future without 
language.  Crows can do this enabling them to have insights and use cars on 
a road to crack nuts or make simple tools to extract insects from holes - 
great apes certainly can, they can even use human language if given 
artificial means to do so without talking (they can't make human sounds, 
but can use symbols on keyboards, computer screens and gestural sign 
language).  But it is only the most sophisticated vertebrates that do this.

comments.text:
+TheRoot Message

part do you think isn't?

Do you disagree that DMT combines with certain receptors in the brain, 
giving an altered state of consciousness and make you trip?  I would say 
this is very well established.

Give someone DMT, and they will trip for a predictable amount of time. Give 
them water, they will not.

Many people, upon sobering up from DMT, will claim they had "Astral 
Projections", Near Death experiences", Psychedelic trips with significant 
messages"  Yada Yada Yada...

This shows us that these experiences are dependent on the DMT, at the very 
least.

Furthermore, we can get other chemicals which produce similar experiences, 
but are different somewhat due to drugs producing different effects and 
different trips...  we can then compare the two or more different 
substances and see brain activity.

What we find is that brain activity in both are rather similar. Certain 
parts of the brain will experience significant decreased activity compared 
with being sober, and others with significant increased activity. This 
shows that it seems that brain activity in certain regions produced from 
particular chemicals produce these altered states of consciousness.

We can then use this information, to predict which parts of the brain are 
responsible for the reactions people call "astral projections" etc...

Through other countless experiments and information collected unrelated to 
drug trips, we have established what general function these parts of the 
brain seem to have, and they seem to correlate strongly with the effects 
they would produce if increased or decreased activity were to happen from 
some chemical. In other words, the theory has predictive capabilities, 
which is essential in establishing its validity. Coincidence?  I think 
not...

This is well established Neuroscience / Psychology, i'm sorry to say. And 
the further we study this, the further we seem to understand this process 
and how drugs can trick people into having profound experiences which they 
may claim is "beyond this world".

There is definitely more to learn, but this is the best explanations we 
have and it is based on countless experiments and our modern understanding 
of the brain.

Some random dude on the internet saying he thinks there actually is more to 
this material life is just frivolous testimonial and doesn't compare with 
actual modern understanding of the brain through science.

comments.text:
+jim jones The human brain works very differently from a computer brain, 
not just "better or worse". In the downside, the human brain doesn't seem 
to have as much storage space as a computer. So whenever it comes to 
acquiring stored information, we humans are forced to access information 
externally rather than from inside our own brain.

On the goodside, our human brain has about the same memory as a computer 
with 2.5 Petabytes (2.500000 GB) of RAM. So we don't need to store as much 
information either. It's stored in memory in bits and pieces and combined 
to produce the information we need.

Neurons are also far better than transistors at communicating with 
eachother. So when you're saying that a computer can run "hundreds of 
processes" simultaneously, I'm not particularly impressed.

Also process is not the same as a physical action done with a physical 
body. It doesn't matter what you're programmed to do, if you don't have a 
body that can obey that program.

Furthermore, it's been stated several times that the work that the Mars 
Rovers do in weeks on mars for instance, can be done in minutes or hours by 
humans. The reason why we don't send humans (yet) is strictly because of 
maintenance costs. Food and protection.

Not to mention the ludicrously bad AI that exists today, that at best 
behaves like a brain-damaged toddler, unless we're talking about game mobs 
who's been programmed to fake a higher intelligence than they actually have.

Also, my original point wasn't even about what is true right now. It was

There are many instances of people gaining savant like powers after a bump 
on the head, so it seems that capacity, or expanded consciousness, be it 
talent in mathematics or memory or art etc, is already there.
To use an analogy, complex mechanical/electrical objects don't benefit by 
being randomly hit hard, unless it is rectifying a fault that has developed 
since new.
If you physically damage a perfectly working machine it doesn't make it 
better than it used to be.
Is there maybe an evolutionary advantage in being relatively dumb, or maybe 
this dumbness is imposed from an outside agency for their evolutionary 
advantage.
Unimpressed by this picture of consciousness, not least because it supposes 
animals can't picture ahead and plan, consciously- there are many well 
documented  studies, for example with crows manufacturing/manipulating 
tools and using them to achieve specific goals in specific unfamiliar tasks 
set for them by experimenters. Some dog owners will also have seen this 
conscious anticipation and planning, that can't be reduced to simple reflex 
actions.﻿

comments.text:
+SpaceManDawn   
Fox squirrels (sciurus niger) do bury nuts and acorns all around their 
territory, while some other species hide their treasures in single caches. 
Not only do they bury acorns in many places, but some squirrels (a Mexican 
squirrel species studied in the American southwest) will also remove the 
germ before burying so that the acorns won't sprout. Fox squirrels manage 
their stores as well, often digging up previously buried nuts and acorns 
and moving them to new locations. It has been shown experimentally that the 
amount they remember to eventually retrieve of what they've buried, 
percentage-wise, is in the nineties.
   None of that is proof of what's in the squirrel's "mind" when it 
performs these behaviors; but it is at least suggestive.
   If the squirrel's consciousness isn't planning for the future, his 
instinct is - and instinct is nearly as unexplained and inexplicable as 
consciousness is. (BTW The professor's theory of consciousness leaves 
instinct out of the question entirely. But then so do most people, 
including many biologists these days, especially in regard to themselves... 
)

+NateMantle To be honest I think you are all aiming for the wrong type of 
prediction. See, these examples are all kinds of things that these animals 
do instinctively (hunting) and they do it all the time. It's what they live 
for, survival and breeding. We, humans, we don't live for certain things. 
One can do whatever he/she wishes to do. So when we decide to go for a swim 
or we want to be able to drive a car, we plan to go out and buy swimming 
shorts because we know we will need those if we go to the pool and we will 
take driving lessons because we know we will need those to be able to drive 
on public roads. If I would tell the average 14 year old that I like red 
cars and show the girl/boy 3 different cars which of one is red and ask 
which car I like, she/he will most likely answer that I like the red one. 
This seems very simple but is at the very core of prediction and 
intelligence. A more relative example would be that when you wake up on 
your day-off (from school or work or anything) you will ask yourself what 
you want to do that day or what you have to do and your brain will rapidly 
start making schedules or plans in order to do those things. These kinds of 
predictions are different from hunting, in the Lion example or following 
the garbage truck, in the crows example, because those animals HAVE to do 
those things in order to survive. They'll HAVE to learn where their preys 
go and where the garbage truck drives around in order to survive and that's 
when instinct and basic learning takes over. They just learn from previous 
experiences instead of CREATING new situations and experiences in their own 
minds, like I noted above.

hibernation without environmental queues, or does the bear simply react to 
the change in the environment (temperature getting colder).

you kept a it in an environment that is constant for longer than a 
winter-summer cycle. If what Michio is saying is correct then if you took a 
black bear from the wild, kept it in a zoo indoors where the climate never 
changes then the bear would never begin preparing for hibernation.

We do know that bears in captivity do not hibernate like bears in the wild 
do, this presents evidence that bears don't plan to hibernate and they just 
react to the environment.

comments.text:
+DunnsDayDash .
How is qualification an illusion?  It's the essence of having the authority 
to say something is or is not a certain way, AGAIN, as a medical doctor is 
authoritatively QUALIFIED to say what is ailing someone, rather than any 
random person off the street.  Without said medical degree, you have no 
authority or right to diagnose, much less prescribe, anything for any 
reason.  The same follows with this:  unless you have an advanced 
mathematics or physics degree, you have no authority.  Period.  The only 
illusion here is the one you have in your mind about credentials and 
authority.
 
Also again, not all opinions are equal.  I refer you back to the first 
paragraph regarding authority.
 
Philosophy and math may have similar origins in time and place, but they 
are absolutely NOT the same.  Logic and math can very well be said to be 
used to find truth, but the means by which they do so are not really the 
same, and the problems that they apply to are entirely different.
 
If you think your logic is unmatched, then I pity you, because I've 
successfully reduced all of your arguments to nothing, so I don't know who 
you've debated, but they were apparently not qualified enough to do so.  
I'm sorry, but you've fundamentally shown a lack of understanding of 
physics, sociology, reasoning, and critical analysis.
 
And please, don't demean yourself.  Please explain which theories you're 
referring to.  Are they physics theories, which require specialized 
training?  Chemistry?  Biology?  Or are they some other kind of theories, 
like something in the soft sciences, such as psychology?  I hope not, 
because with such a profound misunderstanding of basic sociology, that 
couldn't be a sound theory.
 
By the way, we should clarify something here:  "theory" does not equal 
"hypothesis."  A theory, in science, is a well-tested, peer-reviewed idea.  
A true theory in science is not "solved in a matter of hours."  So please, 
by all means, substantiate this claim that you can or have solved theories 
in hours.  Which theories?  I want sources, and verification of who you 
are, and that your name has been attached to said peer-reviewed theory.  
It's time to put your money where your mouth is.
 
Because by the sound of it, you have a "hypothesis."  And since we're 
talking science here, do not misuse the term "theory" to mean something 
that it doesn't, which you clearly don't have.  Germ Theory is a recognized 
theory.  Perturbation Theory is a recognized theory.  In fact, here's a 
short list of other recognized, well-tested, peer-reviewed theories:
-Evolutionary Theory
-Big Bang Theory
-Cosmic Expansion
-Thermodynamics
-General Relativity
 
How about some from the soft sciences, which are also well-tested and 
peer-reviewed:
-Classical Conditioning
-Psychosocial Development
-Behaviorism
-Social Learning
-Functionalism
-Piaget's Stages of Cognitive Development
-Kohlberg's Theory of Moral Development
 
Need I go on?
 
Needless to say, I'm not sure why you think your reasoning capabilities 
make you superior to science.  What has science given us?  Well, let's 
see:  the computer you're using, your phone, your car, planes, trains, 
desks, chairs, tools, beds, television, cameras, water heaters, air 
conditioners, running water, electricity, food preservation, antibiotics, 
artificial hearts, respirators, defibrillators, CDs/DVDs, playing cards, 
vacuum cleaners, glasses (spectacles), glasses (drinking), refrigerators, 
batteries, wiring, radios, ways to preserve food... again, do I really need 
to go on?
 
So forgive me if I fail to see how your reasoning is superior to science, 
much less what you might accomplish with it.  Not to completely bash you; 
perhaps you DO have a good hypothesis.  I haven't read it, but I consider 
myself a philosopher, and preliminarily I have to say that you're not on 
the right track.
 
But hey, what do I know.
 
You may be right that your thoughts are not affected by the ignorance of 
others, but you unfortunately have closed yourself to understanding how the 
world actually works, which is always saddening.  You are also 
unfortunately delusional if you think reasoning alone gives you credibility 
of any kind in regard to physics.  Based on your line of reasoning, you can 
subscribe to any idea you please, regardless of evidence.  Worse, you enter 
into a debate without even understanding the argument of your opposition!  
That's utter failure at the fundamentals of critical analysis, which the 
crux and backbone of philosophy!  Do I even need to list all that you 
didn't understand?
 
At this point, it seems a waste of time to point out that you don't 
understand human nature, either, but you don't.  Nor evolution, or its 
correlation to gravity.  And I mean... not to be incredibly nit-picky, but 
you don't even have the rate of acceleration correct.  Not sure if you 
legitimately didn't know, or were just too lazy to put the whole thing.
 
As Socrates might say, "A philosopher seeks truth, and that truth is based 
in reality.  Truth shapes belief, not the other way around."  You refuse to 
see the world for what it is, and instead only see what you want.  I wish 
you luck, but unfortunately this has ceased being a debate, and is instead 
a lecture.  You've obviously taken nothing from this, but hopefully someone 
else has.
 
Peace.
comments.author: JerkStoleMyName

comments.text:
+DunnsDayDash .
"The answer is gravity. There are no strings."
 
No, that's incorrect.  Again:
1.  Scientists didn't know what held mass together at first.  It was 
postulated that a particle yet to be discovered was responsible.  Years 
later, using the Large Hadron Collider, this particle was discovered:  the 
Higgs boson.  This is the particle that holds other particles together and 
ultimately gives mass its mass.  Without it, particles would not bond 
together.  It has nothing to do with gravity, and as Matthew L. said, 
gravity is the weakest of the four known forces.
2.  You're approaching the idea of "strings" from a narrow mindset.  Simply 
because we cannot see something yet does not mean that it's illogical to 
think it exists, much as with the Higgs boson, and similarly with Dark 
Matter and Dark Energy.  Both of these are not found, at all, period.  Yet 
we can measure their effects on the universe.
3.  You are deeply confusing the ideas of relativity and quantum 
mechanics.  They exist rather independently, though they exist at the same 
time and in the same space.  Normal laws of motion and gravity do not work 
on the quantum scale, and similarly quantum mechanics does not work on the 
macro scale, such as what holds galaxies together.
 
Gravity is actually explained to be a "sheet" that matter sits in.  No, it 
doesn't have positive and negative quantities.  Rather, if two objects of 
larger mass are pulling on a much smaller planet from opposite directions, 
then the planet isn't experiencing negative gravity from one and positive 
from the other, but is rather being pulled by both simultaneously.  Our 
moon doesn't collide because our gravity keeps it close to us.  I'm not 
qualified to explain the specifics of how it got to be where it is, but if 
you're genuinely curious, a quick Google search can find you an answer.
 
I want to preface the next part by saying that I don't believe time travel 
in the SciFi sense to be possible.  That said, ideas of relativity and 
traveling close to the speed of light are sometimes referred to in the same 
sense as "time traveling," because if you traveled near the speed of light 
for X amount of time, everyone else would age a long time while you do not.
 
You seem to have a rather warped idea of what time is, though.  Mass cannot 
have a negative value, either.  Time most certainly IS measurable.  How do 
you think GPS works?  You should look that up.  Simply put, it's done by 
measuring the vibrations of atoms.  Aspects of mass are ALSO relative.  
Your mass changes depending on whether you're in water or not.  And time IS 
universally absolute, in that it is always moving forward.  It may differ 
between you and I, but the very factors that alter our times are the exact 
same for each of us, and it's THIS that matters:  that the FACTORS are the 
same.  Even if you traveled at the speed of light, the same laws of 
relativity apply to us both, just at different extremes.
 
Here, read this:  
http://curiosity.discovery.com/question/what-is-the-fourth-dimension  
Now if you're going to bring up a deity of any kind, you're fighting a 
losing battle, because now you have to substantiate and prove the existence 
of said deity.  I mean physically, quantifiably prove it exists, so you can 
show that it affects the world.  No, I cannot disprove a god, but that's 
not my responsibility.  More importantly, it's completely irrelevant.  From 
your seat, regardless of whether you choose to think a god did it, your 
choice is to either accept that everything started with a singularity, or 
it didn't.  If you choose to believe it did, then you're on the right 
track, even if you want to harbor notions of divine causality.
 
Additionally, equating a god with the Big Bang is kind of silly, because 
"Big Bang" is merely the name we give the reaction, the singularity.  It's 
far more complex than this simple appellation.  And no line of reasoning 
whatsoever deems that the two are the same or equal each other.  I say 
again that you're being arrogant in saying that we absolutely cannot 
understand it, because this is the same hubris that many held for thousands 
and thousands of years regarding many aspects of advancement.  Simply 
because it hasn't happened yet, doesn't mean that it won't.  Granted, it 
may never happen.  But that doesn't mean it's reasonable to say we can't or 
won't.  I will gladly refer you to articles of things we're doing with 
technology now that we never dreamed we could do even a hundred years ago.
 
Since I apparently wasn't clear on one particular point, I'll elaborate:  
If you want to believe that someone is wrong about something, that's your 
right.  However, you make a grave mistake if you think you have any amount 
of credibility simply because you have an opinion.  You want to talk about 
"society;" society has created this idea that all opinions are equal, but 
they're not.  Celestial Mechanics, Gravitational Theory, and Perturbation 
Theory are FAR, FAR from simple.  The math required to understand what 
Newton alone figured out is not simple; it's advanced calculus.  I don't 
recall saying quantum mechanics has anything to do with how the planets 
orbit, but if I did, I apologize (though I really doubt I did).
 
If you have some beef with String Theory, then you're better off getting a 
highly advanced math and physics degree, so you can mathematically show why 
it's BS.  Until that point, you have nothing more than an opinion, and 
sorry to say, not even a good one.  I don't claim to be a big supporter or 
anything, but I at least recognize that it's a widely-supported theory by 
experts in the field, who know WAY more than I do.  I simply try to 
understand as much as I can about it, and await the day that it may be 
completed so we can see what can be done with it.
 
And no, you have no credibility in regard to physics compared to Kaku, and 
not to be insulting, but you're delusional if you think you do.  That's 
akin to saying you have the same credibility as a doctor, but no medical 
degree, or as a lawyer, but no law degree.  He's been to school for the 
stuff in his field, which GIVES him the credibility to talk about physics 
and string theory.
 
At no point did I say that credentials determine what type of person you 
are.  Not once did I say such a thing.  So I'll say again:  they give 
credence to you have credibility as a professional in your chosen field, 
again like a doctor, lawyer, what-have-you.
 
And if you reeeeally think that there's not an inequality, then you really 
need to take a good Sociology course.  I'm not even going to elaborate on 
this one, and will only say that social class COMPLETELY affects a child's 
ability to be "whatever they want."  It is absolutely NOT equal.
 
To be completely blunt, I'm not the one who is apparently feeding off of 
societal notions:  you are, since you think all opinions are equal, and 
everyone has the same chance at life and education.  These are 
categorically—thoroughly and completely--incorrect.
 
And I COMPLETELY encourage you to prove him wrong.  Not in the "I have an 
opinion" sort of way, but the "I've gone through advanced math and physics 
courses and have disproven the theory with mathematics" way.  In fact, if 
you do, you'll likely get a Nobel Prize for it.  Seriously, you probably 
would.  Go for it.  It's not impossible.  It IS impossible if you don't 
have the schooling first, but not after.
 
Obviously you don't understand black holes, or you wouldn't have said, 
"nothing is destroyed."  Look up what happens to stuff that's eaten by a 
black hole.
 
By the way, Newton started working on his theories in the late 1600s.  
Those ideas weren't finished until roughly the early 1800s.  So it took 
about 150 years—count that again, just in case—until we (man in general) 
had a much better understanding of celestial mechanics.  If you're 
reeeeally going to use the age of the theory as an argument, then you 
should probably know in advance that it's a poor argument.  Just saying.
 
So yes, by all means, go ahead writing your own theory.  If it isn't based 
in science, though, then you're going to have a really, REALLY difficult 
time with that.  I wish you luck, though!  It'll take more than luck, of 
course, but whatever.  You obviously know more than I!  Unless, of 
course... wait a second... yep, I think I've consistently exposed flaws in 
your arguments.  That doesn't necessarily prove who is more intelligent, 
because I certainly won't claim to be (since I cannot know or prove that), 
but I CAN claim that I have a far, far better understanding of science, 
based on how this discussion has gone.
 
And quite honestly of grammar as well.  Just saying.
 
So I'll tell you the same thing I've told others:  resorting to 
name-calling will not, in any way, help validate your arguments, and will 
only succeed in making you look silly.  It certainly doesn't hurt my 
feelings, but if it makes you feel better to think so, then go right ahead 
deluding yourself.
 
To +Matthew L., I'm not sure if you were referring to me about being "as 
qualified as Kaku."  If you meant me, then absolutely not!  I never said 
such a thing, nor would I.  The things I'm discussing are basic premises 
and ideas that anyone who is curious can research.  They are what the 
layman can understand, as I am merely a layman.  I know nothing of the math 
behind String Theory, or multi-verse theories, or physics.  I'm simply 
enthusiastic about science.  That said, I was challenging Dunns, who bashed 
Kaku, as if he knew more about physics, which is, quite frankly, obviously 
not the case.  I thank you, though, for the compliments.
comments.author: JerkStoleMyName

comments.text:
+DunnsDayDash .
The first thing you were talking about--that which keeps particles 
together, was finally uncovered in Geneva using the LHC:  the Higgs Boson.

It is, in essence, what gives matter its mass.  When looking at everything 
that has matter on the smallest scale, there is more distance between each 
particle that there is of the particles themselves.  Here's a kind of 
graphic example:

o    o    o    o
o    o    o    o

The space between particles causes physicists to wonder what held us, and 
everything else, together.  They postulated a particle, which they 
discovered in the recent years (within the last two, I believe).

As far as dimensions, there are four, the fourth being time/space-time.  
And +Brian Rush is correct, that the dimensions are not outside of ours, 
but are layered on top/inside and are very much a part of our universe.

The easiest way to explain multiple dimensions is in this example (not 
mine):

Imagine an ant on a flat piece of paper.  You've drawn a square around it, 
and the ant cannot move outside of the square, and is relegated to this 2-D 
plane.  You tell the ant, "Leave your square," but the ant says, "I can't."

You tell him, "Sure you can, just hope off the paper into the third 
dimension!"

"What third dimension," he asks?  "I'm stuck on this paper!"

"The third dimension!  Just leave the paper--step into the third dimension, 
and land back outside the square!"

This is similar to how its explained regarding other dimensions.  You're 
now in a 3-D box, and some being talks to you, saying, "Just step into the 
fifth/eighth/etc dimension!"

As far as the big bang, you can call it what you like, but evidence gives 
us great reason to think that everything started at one point.  No deity or 
religion is even remotely close to the big bang, as those are all myth with 
no foundation at all in reality (no tangible, verifiable evidence), while 
the big bang is a well-tested theory.  By the way, in science, a "theory" 
is the highest appellation an idea can attain.  You can try to use that 
term against it, but then you'd be forgetting that we call the spread of 
disease Germ Theory, or the force that pulls us down and keeps the planets 
in orbit Gravitational Theory (and also Perturbation Theory).  So just 
because any god is unprovable, does not mean that the big bang is also.  If 
the big bang is ultimately unprovable, then it's because it's unprovable 
(though there's no reason to yet believe it is).  It's still undeniable, if 
you understand the evidence, to think that such an event likely occurred.

Also, if you start understanding quantum mechanics, then String Theory 
seems less like bullshit.  It's not finished yet by any means, but many 
would've said the same to Newton or Einstein before those ideas could be 
tested.  In fact, it's quite common, and also quite arrogant, so say we 
cannot or will not discover or learn those things.  Just because you 
cannot, does not mean that others cannot either.  After all, Newton was 
only one of the founders that explained our solar system, but ultimately 
didn't explain all of it.  Newton reached a limit.  It was Huygens who 
expanded on them, and then Laplace after that.

And it might just be me who feels this way, but you really have no 
credibility to say that Kaku is wrong, unless you're also a physicist, in 
which case I encourage you to submit your credentials.  Simply saying "he's 
wrong" does you no justice.  There's actually a good reason why he's 
regarded as one of the greatest theoretical physicists of our time, and 
it's not because people simply like him.

Anyway, I hope this all makes sense!  Here's a source that explains 
dimensions better:  
http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/physics/imagining-other-dimensions.html
comments.author: JerkStoleMyName

top_comment.text:
First off, that's not consciousness, that's intelligence. And as far as 
planning ahead goes, mice are actually ahead of us. Humans are rarely 
capable of doing much more than what they are told how to do. But mice can 
actually look at a complex mechanism and devise an "attack plan" for 
getting what they want out of it.

Where humans go beyond animals is our ability to set non-pragmatic goals. 
For instance, there is very little evolutionary pragmatic use for painting 
or music. Yet we value it greatly. A mouse would not. It would only value 
something that reduces pain and maximizes physical satisfaction. Our 
ability to value something that has no actual value other than that which 
we give it, is where we are unique.﻿

comments.text:
+Christopowaaa
The idea is to test the abilities of both to solve a range of problems, 
with all elements not directly related to independent brain function being 
eliminated, and then comparing the results in terms of successful 
solutions, and time to achieve a solution.

There can be some issues in defining what are "elements not directly 
related to independent brain function". For instance, relative to its size, 
a mouse would have better land speed traversing through a maze, compared to 
a human traveling a scaled-up version of the same maze. A human using 
written or verbal clues in human language would have a clear unfair 
advantage over a mouse which doesn't use the same language (and, possibly, 
no language at all). On a less obvious level, any information a human has 
learned during his life time could pose an unfair advantage, just as 
allowing a mouse to pre-memorize a maze would equally be unfair. Also, 
visual clues may be received differently by humans and mice, due to 
different eye configuration. A mouse could also rely more on scent than a 
human would tend to do. And, obviously, as I've stated before, motivation 
is also a factor, as both the mouse and the human must be equally motivated 
to actually solve the problem involved.
Eliminating every single such factor, at least to the point where remaining 
factors are negligible, does require some careful planning and work.

Once all such factors are eliminated, then, and only then, can you compare 
intelligence, simply as the ability to reach correct solutions to similar 
(read: isomorphic) problems at higher speed. This is how Alan Turing 
defined intelligence, and is pretty much to how Michio Kaku is defining 
"Conciousness" in the above video.
comments.author: Saar Korren

conclusion to me. However, I am more than willing to be persuaded &

Humans acquire & apply knowledge differently to mice, meaning that when

comments.text:
+Saar Korren I'm not debating that scientists said it (if by scientists, 
you mean the author of *The Immortal Cell* and his cohorts who coined the 
term), I'm debating the semantics -- why use the word "immortal" other than 
to attract extra attention to the process?

Furthermore, if you set aside "physical damage", then *everything* is 
immortal. All energetic configurations naturally decay over time, but the 
energy is never destroyed. When we say something "dies", we really mean 
that its specific energetic or chemical configuration falls apart and 
energy dissipates into other configurations. Of course if you remove the 
possibility of "physical damage" (or, physical interactions which result in 
the whole or partial destruction of the configuration), then the 
configuration will be preserved, but that can also be achieved with other 
means like freezing a biological cell at absolute zero -- it doesn't mean 
that biological cells are "immortal", it just means that they're incredibly 
stable in certain environments, and slightly unstable in others, such that 
they naturally decay over time. 

A cancer cell can die due to failure of an organelle caused by radioactive 
exposure, causing the cell's processes to corrupt or otherwise fail.  

A human being can die due to failure of an organ caused by cancer 
proliferation, causing the organ's processes to corrupt or otherwise fail. 

So, neither are "immortal" in the sense that they transcend mortality and 
result in an eternal configuration or process.

Hi Chris,  Sorry it's taken so long for me to reply.  Here is a condensed 
version of my theory, which addresses your point.

Central Tenets

1. Reality has two complementary aspects: the physical and the conceptual.

2. Minds link the physical and conceptual aspects of reality together, so 
that ideas can influence what happens in the physical world, and events in 
the physical world can influence ideas.

3. Minds are huge ever-changing yet stable patterns of information that 
continuously interact with the physical world and that of concepts. 

4. It is the pattern itself that is conscious.

Evidence

1. Children fail to develop minds if they are isolated from the conceptual 
aspect of reality; they become animals.

2. Patterns are the only things we know of that are both physical and 
conceptual.

Conclusion

We are more than flesh and blood, we are “conscious patterns”.
comments.author: George Simpson

comments.text:
+
010101001010101010101010001010000110101001010100010101001110001010010100100010100101010101001001010X 
For one, it is incorrect to associate consciousness with a thermostat.  He 
claims a thermostat has a "unit of consciousness," which he conveniently 
does not clearly define further than extremely vague language.  He says 
that a thermostat "senses" the temperature around it.  What does he mean by 
"senses?" A thermostat responds to thermodynamic properties of the air 
surrounding it through the transmission of electrical forces between 
colliding atoms, and those changes create a cascade of physical and 
chemical transmissions in a linear fashion. There is no structure in this 
system which builds a model of the stimuli. The thermostat does not "sense" 
anything, unless you want to change the definition of what "sense" means.

A flower does not "understand" the temperature or gravity of its 
surroundings, it only behaves according to reflexes inherent to its 
neurochemical structure, but again there is no neurological structure which 
builds a predictive model to understand the outside world.  

To understand something, that indicates a predictive learning algorithm 
which can predict the outcomes of a system based on the networked structure 
of the algorithm. It is still a cascade of chemical and electrical signals, 
but the important element here is the *structure* of the signals. 
 Consciousness does not comprise mere physical interactions between 
molecules, but an overall meaningful arrangement of those molecules who's 
final states are determined by an algorithm built (learned) by prior 
sensory input.

comments.text:
+fourPOdimethylT How are we to know when the line is drawn in a species we 
cannot communicate with between conscious planning and instinctive planning?

Observation. The only animal we have observed that is close to our level 
of consciousness are dolphins.

Dogs were once thought to be near our consciousness level, because the 
theory was that dogs were bred from lone wolves who had made an 
active decision to leave their pack in favor of humans. This theory was 
later discounted, and now wolves were thought to have followed human groups 
because of their food scraps. Because their instinct is to eat for survival.

That 'line' you speak of is really subjective though, because of the reason 
you stated. Consider this, I hold out a peanut for a squirrel. What will 
the squirrel do? In theory, genetic instinct says he should perform the 
same action & make the same decisions nearly every time I do this. But some 
squirrels will get close & run away, some get close & attempt to take it 
from my hand. On the flip side, this could also be thought of as 
conditioning, which replaces instinct with a learned behavior aKa training. 
Food is the classic go-to for training conditioned responses.

captions.text:
In the entire universe the two greatest scientific
mysteries are first of all the origin of the

universe itself. And second of all the origin
of intelligence. Believe it or not, sitting

on our shoulders is the most complex object
that Mother Nature has created in the known

universe. You have to go at least 24 trillion
miles to the nearest star to find a planet

that may have life and may have intelligence.
And yet our brain only consumes about 20-30

watts of power and yet it performs calculations
better than any large supercomputer. So it's

a mystery. How is the brain wired up? And
if we can figure that out what can we do with
it to enhance our mental capabilities.

When you look at the brain and all the parts
of the brain they don't seem to make any sense

at all. The visual part of the brain is way
in the back, for example. Why is the brain

constructed the way it is? Is this nothing
but an accident of evolution? Well one way

to look at it is through evolution. That is,
the back of the brain is a so-called reptilian

brain. The most ancient primitive part of
the brain that governs balance, territoriality,

mating. And so the very back of the brain
is also the kind of brain that you find in

reptiles. Now when I was a child I would go
to the science museum and look at the snakes

sometimes and they would stare back at me.
And I would wonder, "What are they thinking

about?" Well, I think now I know. What they're
thinking about was, "Is this person lunch?"

Then we have the center part of the brain
going forward and that's a so-called monkey

brain, the mammalian brain. The brain of emotions.
The brain of social hierarchies. And then

finally the front of the brain is the human
brain, especially the prefrontal cortex. This

is where rational thinking is. And when you
ask yourself a question where am I anyway.

The answer is right behind your forehead.
That's where you really are.

Well, I have a theory of consciousness which
tries to wrap it all up together. There've

been about 20,000 or so papers written about
consciousness and no consensus. Never in the

history of science have so many people devoted
so much time to produce so little. Well, I'm

a physicist and when we physicists look at
a mysterious object the first thing we try

to do is to create a model. A model of this
object in space. And then we hit the play

button and run it forward in time. This is
how Newton was able to come up with the theory

of gravity. This is how Einstein came up with
relativity. So I tried to use this in terms

of the human brain and evolution. So what
I'm saying is I have a new theory of consciousness

based on evolution. And that is consciousness
is the number of feedback loops required to

create a model of your position in space with
relationship to other organisms and finally
in relationship to time.

So think of the consciousness of a thermostat.
I believe that even a lowly thermostat has

one unit of consciousness. That is, it senses
the temperature around it. And then we have

a flower. A flower has maybe, maybe ten units
of consciousness. It has to understand the

temperature, the weather, humidity, where
gravity is pointing. And then finally we go

to the reptilian brain which I call level
1 consciousness and reptiles basically have

a very good understanding of their position
in space, especially because they have to

lunge out and grab prey. Then we have level
2 consciousness, the monkey consciousness.

The consciousness of emotions, social hierarchies,
where are we in relationship to the tribe.
And then where are we as humans.

As humans we are at level 3. We run simulations
into the future. Animals apparently don't

do this. They don't plan to hibernate. They
don't plan the next day's agenda. They have

no conception of tomorrow to the best of our
ability. But that's what our brain does. Our

brain is a prediction machine. And so when
we look at the evolution from the reptilian

brain to the mammalian brain to the prefrontal
cortex, we realize that is the process of

understanding our position in space with respect
to others -- that is emotions -- and finally
running simulations into the future.

title: Michio Kaku: Consciousness Can be Quantified
